comment._content:
On October 19, President Woodrow Wilson rode in a private railroad car to Princeton, New Jersey, his nominal home town and legal voting place. He arrived with his fiancee, Edith Bolling Galt [they were wed on December 18], went to the polling place and voted "yes" on the Woman Suffrage Amendment, then left after being in town for ninety minutes. This paragraph appeared the next day in the Daily Princetonian:

PRESIDENT WILSON HERE; VOTES "YES" FOR SUFFRAGE
President Woodrow Wilson yesterday made his second visit to Princeton since college opened. His private car arrived at about 12.20, and he proceeded at once to the seventh district polls in the house of Engine Company No. 3 00 Chambers Street. After voting, the President paid a visit to Professor W. U. Vreeland, and later to Dean Fine. He left Princeton at 1.45 p. m.

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: arbo: the following will hopefully address your questions about our approach to this collection with respect to how the captions were handled. It was written by the chief of the Prints & Photographs Division. Additionally, please see our webpage of frequently asked questions about the Flickr project in general: www.loc.gov/rr/print/flickr_pilot_faq.html In 2004-06, the Prints & Photographs Division was delighted to receive enough funding to scan all 40,000 glass negatives in the Bain Collection. (See www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/ggbain/digitizing.html.) The funding also had limits, and we had to find an expeditious way to provide basic captions. Rather than decipher and transcribe the handwritten titles and dates directly from the glass plates (very time consuming and thus costly), we relied on a typed set of caption cards that Library staff had made some decades ago by looking at the Bain company’s handwritten index cards as well as notes on the paper sleeves that housed the negatives. The information on the Bain caption cards and sleeves was not always identical to the info on the negatives, but it was usually quite close. We tried to be explicit about the “incomplete” aspects of the titles by putting a note in each record to indicate the preliminary nature of the information: "Title from unverified data provided by the Bain News Service on the negatives or caption cards." Having the digital images go online was a foundation step that made future projects possible. People could now more easily compare the titles on the negatives and the information from the caption cards by enlarging the photo image to see the letters on the negative clearly. Then, flesh out abbreviations, correct misspellings, and add subject information. That’s where the Flickr project has made such an important contribution–the reconciliation and verification of data is now well underway! Some 9,000 Bain photos are in Flickr, which means far better captions for almost 25% of the collection already.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Since you asked, it's worth mentioning two more things .... (1) Flickr opened The Commons in large part so that people could contribute better information about the pictures in many libraries, archives, and museums. Pictures with limited descriptions and institutions with limited resources are all too common. (See www.flickr.com/commons/ ) If you enjoy seeing how picture puzzles are solved, the National Library of Ireland photostream is well worth a look at www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/ (2) We incorporate the valuable new information that Flickr members provide into the catalog records at the Library of Congress pretty quickly, along with a link that connects to the longer narrative comments in Flickr. But we aren't too often able to re-load those improved records back into Flickr. Also, the new, fuller info might be in a subject note rather than the title; we leave the title as the Bain News Service provided it unless their information is completely wrong. Here's a typical example of an updated record that was reloaded to Flickr in 2012, www.loc.gov/pictures/item/ggb2005014062/ Please keep the improved descriptions coming! Helena (LOC)
